title: Einstein said “the definition of insanity is doing the same thing yet expecting different results.” What is your interpretation? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have a better version: “The definition of insanity is believing any quote you find on the internet which is attributed to Albert Einstein.” There is no evidence that Einstein said this, besides dozens upon dozens of “quote collections” you find online, which conveniently have no source. This quote has also, in the past, been attributed to Mark Twain, Benjamin Franklin, and an ancient Chinese proverb. The earliest written reference anyone has found goes back to either 1981, in a Narcotics Anonymous Pamphlet[1] (albeit with a slightly different wording), or in the exact same wording from 1983, in a book by Rita Mae Brown[2] , in which she attributes it to a fictional author within her story. Einstein died in 1955 — more than 25 years earlier. There's practically a cottage industry in manufacturing fake, meaningful sounding quotes, and then putting them on top of images of “smart" people like Einstein, Twain and Franklin. It reminds me of this old inspirational poster:  That's my personal interpretation: Einstein said no such thing, and it's a lesson for us all that such a pointless lie has become so widespread. It's also a terrible definition of madness. Quite a lot of science is doing the same thing over and over again, to check that you weren't wrong in the first place!  On the other hand, maybe the fact that I keep having to write these answers to combat the nonsense spread around by the “fans” of people like Einstein and Tesla is evidence that I am the mad one. After all, I do keep doing the same thing over and over again…. Footnotes[1] https://web.archive.org/web/20121202030403/http://www.amonymifoundation.org/uploads/NA_Approval_Form_Scan.pdf[2] Rita Mae Brown - Wikiquote

The assertion in question has been attributed to Albert Einstein without proof - despite the thoroughness with which his public statements were documented. Which is a classic example of the ‘appeal to authority’ ploy that is fundamental to many efforts to short-circuit rational due diligence - the prime example being religious faith. It is highly improbable Einstein said any such thing. But say he had? We still have an obligation to the truth and our own well-being to test such assertions. The operative word in this declaration is “insanity”. What is meant by ‘insanity’ in this context? If the allusion were to a general state of clinical insanity it fails. Subsequent to an episode of “doing the same thing (repeatedly) yet expecting different results” most of us go on to think and behave sanely. (Note‘repeatedly’ essential to saving the assertion from being farcical and dismissed out of hand since repeating an action once or twice to make sure we ‘got it right’ is wise not insane. ‘Measure twice - cut once’? And when it comes to “expecting different results” that occurs in science when someone gets a result at odds with priorly amassed and confirmed data. In daily life it is seen as prudent to ‘double check’- and in science make that quadruple check - then ask all peers to do so too. Two simple changes can make the statement viable and useful. Changes made, the aphorism becomes ‘the definition of stupidity is repeatedly doing the same thing yet expecting different results’.

Perhaps you refer to Einstein saying: “I am not quite sure if the Universe is infinite, but I know that human stupidity is”. Otherwise, the thing with insanity being doing the same thing over and over, it is not necessarily true. Many times in sports, an athlete repeats the same procedure, and it may be successful after a few tries. Also in science, experiments are repeated, not identical, but with little difference, to make sure you will cover a narrow range. Sometimes repetition of things is necessary. Whatever the author of the saying intended, perhaps it was about making a change when you see it does not work that specific way, but again, it’s debatable. I do not think it is insane to do things repeatedly when situation requires.

That particular quote has been floating around and been attributed to all manner of people. It’s patently false. It might be a definition of stupidity, or sheer stubbornness… but not insanity. Insanity is a broad, general term for all manner of mental disturbances ranging from severe depression, bipolar disease, schizophrenia (or “schizo-affective syndrome”) and others. Many of these people are entirely rational and even quite bright. They may also be delusional, experience hallucinations, have brains that run in “overdrive”…. But most would very likely agree that doing the same thing over and over and expecting different results would be a good sign of stupidity.

Well I don't no whether he said this or not but yes,I will explain what I understand by that quote. I will give you an example:Let's assume that a person puts 50% of his efforts in studying and scores average marks. The next time he has kept his expectations high but again puts only 50% of his efforts from his part. This situation is a good example for this quote. He is insane for he puts the same amount of efforts in both the tests but expects higher marks in the second one. If you expect to see a change in your results,you need to bring a change in the amount of hard work and efforts you are putting in the work lest you will be considered a fool.

As other answers have said, Einstein did not say this. But this false attribution seems a bit more fun than the others, since Einstein is known to be unhappy with the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics, so much that he said his famous quote: “[God] does not play dice with the universe”. Anyway, the argument was only about how to interpret a certain physical phenomenon. Both sides of the argument would agree that when quantum mechanics is involved, doing the exactly same thing twice but ending up with different results is possible. Therefore, not only Einstein did not say this, but this is completely wrong when we look at the fields that he worked at.
My interpretation: This is not the definition of insanity.Einstein never said that.

He said this in regard to the idea of war in general. Literally, it is impossible to do the same thing over and over because the environment where said thing is being done will always be slightly different. As an example, shining light in a vacuum will travel at the speed of c, though sometimes it will travel undetectably slower, due to an atom or some other impurity getting in the way. Nonetheless, shining a light in a vacuum multiple times would probably be a waste of time and energy.

Two issues. One, there is no resource which can attribute this to Albert Einstein, because he didn’t say or write it; and two, the scientific process requires doing the same thing over and over again to confirm your results. Endless repetition is also what makes great athletes, musicians, and actors. It’s how we master even basic skills. How do you learn any skill except by practice? We’re not like computers or machines which can be programmed once and do things exactly as instructed. Doing the same thing over and over is how you get to Carnegie Hall, or toilet train a child.

The first is that he very likely never said that. The second is that it’s the definition of practice. Not everything, but many things require repetition to gain skill. Lift weights. Go jogging. You’re doing the same thing over and over and over and you get better results. That’s how muscle memory works.

Einstein said “the definition of insanity is doing the same thing yet expecting different results.” What is your interpretation? Einstein is crazy and insane,not a joke,say this or not mr Alon.His theories didn’t change any thing,Workers do.

As has been pointed out - this is not an Albert Einstein quote, and is not a “definition”. That said, it’s really just an alternate phrasing for something my stepfather was fond of saying back in the 80s: If you always do what you’ve always done, you’ll always get what you’ve always got. In other words if you’re not pleased with the way things are, change something.aka Troubleshooting 101:)
First of all, Einstein never said that, it’s just some stupid meme that makes its way around. Anyway, it’s not insanity, musicians and athletes call it “practicing”, and they do it a LOT.

There are quite a lot of careers that can be made by doing the same thing over and over and expecting a different result, so I think this false quote is silly. Software QA and Safey Inspector come to mind.

THAT IS NOT the definition of insanity and Einstein never said it. Sanity is when one is out of touch with reality (psychotic) and is not responsible for their actions under the eyes of the law. You can’t discern from right and wrong. This fucked up bullshit, totally pisses me off. You people should be flogged. Plus it makes you look incredibly stupid. If you didn’t know it now you do.

I don’t think it’s actually true that Einstein ever said this, it’s more of an urban legend. But regardless, I think the sentiment of the statement makes a whole lot more sense if you replace the word “insanity” with “futility”.
What Einstein actually said was that falsley attributing a trite quote to someone is a sign of insanity unless you make a whole lot of money from it, then you are just a grifter.
Not only it is neither the definition of insanity nor an Einstein’s quote. It is also how science works to prove points, with method.
Last time I checked, Vaas Montenegro was the main antagonist in Far Cry 3, not Albert Einstein. Far Cry 3 - Vaas' The Definition of Insanity (Full Quote, Vaas Montenegro)
This keeps popping up in my feed, so I will answer it;  There you have it, the man never did lie, and there clearly is his name attributed to this quote so it must be true.
It is kind of same thing i hear from villain of far cry 3.  image source - google
Don't do the same thing twice, unless just looking for confirmation!
